analogy: {"A is to B as C is to D": "K2CoF6 is to Cs2CoF6 as Rb2CoF6 is to Rb2CoF6_prediction. Reasoning: For A2CoF6 compounds the formation energy varies only weakly with the alkali cation (K, Rb, Cs). K2CoF6 and Cs2CoF6 have nearly identical formation energies (-2.46735 and -2.47295 eV/atom), so Rb2CoF6 (alkali between K and Cs) should lie very close to their values. Rb has an atomic number exactly midway between K and Cs, so a linear interpolation (average) of the K and Cs values is a simple, justified estimate. Steps: (1) identify close chemical analogues with same transition metal (Co) and same anion (F); (2) assume smooth/weak dependence of formation energy on alkali cation size; (3) interpolate between K and Cs values to predict Rb value."}

K2CoF6 is to Cs2CoF6 as K-site -> Cs-site substitution is to K-site -> Rb-site substitution. In other words, the change in formation energy when the A-site cation in A2CoF6 is changed from K to Cs is very small (ΔE ≈ -0.00560 eV/atom). Rb+ has an ionic radius intermediate between K+ and Cs+, so Rb2CoF6 should have a formation energy intermediate between K2CoF6 and Cs2CoF6. I therefore interpolate between K2CoF6 and Cs2CoF6 (using either a simple midpoint or a linear interpolation by ionic radius) to predict the formation energy of Rb2CoF6. Steps: 1) note E(K2CoF6) = -2.467351918277778 and E(Cs2CoF6) = -2.472950881034483; 2) since Rb+ radius is between K+ and Cs+, take the midpoint or perform linear interpolation by ionic radius to get E(Rb2CoF6) ≈ -2.47005 eV/atom.
code:
from math import isclose
# Reference energies (eV/atom)
E_K = -2.467351918277778
E_Cs = -2.472950881034483
# Shannon ionic radii for 6-fold coordination (Å): K+ 1.38, Rb+ 1.52, Cs+ 1.67
r_K, r_Rb, r_Cs = 1.38, 1.52, 1.67
# Linear interpolation by radius
slope = (E_Cs - E_K) / (r_Cs - r_K)
E_Rb_interp = E_K + slope * (r_Rb - r_K)
# Midpoint
E_Rb_mid = 0.5 * (E_K + E_Cs)
E_Rb_interp, E_Rb_mid

analogy: {"description":"I use the Rb2MF6 series trend vs. d-electron count. Rb2MnF6 (Mn, d5) has formation energy -2.9007038969923373 eV/atom and Rb2NiF6 (Ni, d8) has -2.389794803888885 eV/atom. The formation energy becomes less negative as d-electron count increases from Mn to Ni. Co is d7, midway between d5 and d8, so I linearly interpolate between the Mn (d5) and Ni (d8) values to estimate Rb2CoF6 (d7). Steps: 1) identify anchor compounds and their d counts and energies; 2) perform linear interpolation for d7; 3) report the interpolated value as the predicted formation energy per atom for Rb2CoF6.", "title":"Analogy"}

Analogy and reasoning:
1) Identify close structural/chemical analogues in the dataset: many A2BCl6 salts with Rb on the A-site (Rb2MnCl6 -1.8396 eV/atom, Rb2PtCl6 -1.6357, Rb2SnCl6 -1.8885, Rb2WCl6 -1.7851, etc.). These indicate typical formation energies for Rb2BCl6 compounds fall in roughly -1.6 to -2.4 eV/atom.
2) Assume Co in Rb2CoCl6 will behave chemically similar to neighboring transition metals (Mn/Fe/Ni) in this family. Use Rb2MnCl6 (-1.8396 eV/atom) as a proxy baseline for Rb2CoCl6 because Mn is the closest available B-site analogue.
3) Use the chemical analogy of halide substitution: replacing Cl by the more electronegative F typically strengthens ionic/covalent bonding and makes formation energies more negative. From observed Cl->Br->I trends in the dataset (Cl generally more negative than Br and much more negative than I) and chemical reasoning, estimate the Cl->F shift to be on the order of -0.2 to -0.3 eV/atom (i.e., F-stabilized relative to Cl).
4) Construct the analogy explicitly: Rb2MnCl6 is to Rb2MnF6 as Rb2CoCl6 is to Rb2CoF6 — i.e., the stabilizing effect of replacing Cl with F for a given A2BCl6 should be similar across neighboring transition-metal B-sites. Using Rb2MnCl6 as the chloride baseline and applying a −0.21 eV/atom F-stabilization yields the estimate for Rb2CoF6.
5) Calculation: formation_energy(Rb2CoF6) ≈ formation_energy(Rb2MnCl6) − 0.21 eV/atom ≈ -1.83955 − 0.21 ≈ -2.05 eV/atom.
Uncertainty/assumptions: the estimate assumes (a) Rb2CoCl6 would be close in stability to Rb2MnCl6, and (b) Cl->F stabilization magnitude ~0.2 eV/atom. These are approximate; expect an uncertainty of a few 0.1 eV/atom.
code:
# Python used for the numeric estimate
rb2_mn_cl6 = -1.839553694770114
cl_to_f_shift = -0.21
rb2_co_f6_estimate = rb2_mn_cl6 + cl_to_f_shift
rb2_co_f6_estimate

analogy: {"title":"Analogy","description":"I use an analogy based on how changing the alkali cation (K -> Rb -> Cs) shifts formation energies for the same transition-metal hexafluoride, and how formation energy changes across the 3d transition-metal series for the same alkali. Specifically: K2NiF6 is to Cs2NiF6 as K2CoF6 is to Rb2CoF6. Steps: 1) Estimate K2CoF6 by linear interpolation along the transition-metal series between K2MnF6 and K2NiF6 (Mn->Fe->Co->Ni). 2) Estimate the energetic shift caused by replacing K by Rb using the known K->Cs shift for the Ni system, scaled by Rb's fractional position between K and Cs (using typical ionic radii). 3) Apply that K->Rb shift to the estimated K2CoF6 to obtain Rb2CoF6. Numerical values used: K2MnF6 = -2.888768716936781 eV/atom, K2NiF6 = -2.384495597166662 eV/atom, Cs2NiF6 = -2.466306513333333 eV/atom. From Mn->Ni across 3 steps we get a per-element change of +0.16809 eV/atom; K2CoF6 ~ -2.55259 eV/atom. K->Cs shift for Ni is -0.08181 eV/atom; using ionic-radius-based fraction for Rb between K and Cs (~0.483) gives a K->Rb shift ~ -0.0395 eV/atom. Final estimate Rb2CoF6 ~ -2.592 eV/atom.","type":"string"}
code:
K2Mn = -2.888768716936781
K2Ni = -2.384495597166662
Cs2Ni = -2.466306513333333
# per-element slope Mn->Ni (3 steps)
slope = (K2Ni - K2Mn) / 3.0
# Co is Mn + 2 steps
K2Co_est = K2Mn + 2.0 * slope
# K->Cs shift for Ni
shift_KCs_Ni = Cs2Ni - K2Ni
# fraction position of Rb between K and Cs (approx from ionic radii)
fraction_Rb = 0.483
shift_KRb = fraction_Rb * shift_KCs_Ni
Rb2Co_est = K2Co_est + shift_KRb
K2Mn, K2Ni, Cs2Ni, slope, K2Co_est, shift_KCs_Ni, shift_KRb, Rb2Co_est
math:
\text{Interpolate K2CoF6: }s=\frac{E(K2NiF6)-E(K2MnF6)}{3},\quad E(K2CoF6)=E(K2MnF6)+2s.

\text{K->Rb shift: }\Delta_{K\to Rb}\approx f\cdot\Delta_{K\to Cs}^{(Ni)},\;f\approx0.483.

\text{Then }E(Rb2CoF6)=E(K2CoF6)+\Delta_{K\to Rb}.

analogy:
I construct a two-part analogy to estimate Rb2CoF6 by separately accounting for (1) A-site cation changes (K <-> Rb <-> Cs) and (2) halide substitution (Cl <-> F).

Analogy 1 (A-site effect): K2MnCl6 : Cs2MnCl6 :: K2CoCl6 : Rb2CoCl6
- From dataset: K2MnCl6 = -1.641455737 and Cs2MnCl6 = -1.696653020, so K -> Cs (larger A-site) changes formation energy by about -0.0552 eV/atom (becomes slightly more negative). Rb is intermediate in size between K and Cs, so I assume K -> Rb produces a smaller negative shift (~ -0.03 eV/atom).

Analogy 2 (halide effect): Cs2TiCl6 : Cs2TiI6 :: K2CoCl6 : K2CoF6
- From dataset: Cs2TiCl6 = -2.061580076 and Cs2TiI6 = -1.508881837, so Cl -> I increases the formation energy by +0.5527 eV/atom (I less stabilizing than Cl). Fluorine is more electronegative and smaller than chlorine, so going Cl -> F should make the compound more stable (more negative formation energy). Based on the magnitude of halide-driven changes in the dataset, I estimate a typical Cl -> F stabilization on the order of -0.30 to -0.50 eV/atom; I use -0.40 eV/atom as a reasonable mid-point.

Putting the two analogies together to estimate Rb2CoF6:
1) Use K2MnCl6 (-1.6415) as a proxy for K2CoCl6 (Co and Mn are nearby 3d metals); I adjust slightly for Co being perhaps a bit less stabilizing than Mn, yielding an estimated K2CoCl6 ≈ -1.62 eV/atom.
2) Apply Cl -> F stabilization: K2CoF6 ≈ -1.62 + (-0.40) = -2.02 eV/atom.
3) Apply A-site K -> Rb small negative shift (~ -0.03): Rb2CoF6 ≈ -2.02 + (-0.03) = -2.05 eV/atom.

Thus the chain of analogies is: K2MnCl6 : Cs2MnCl6 :: K2CoCl6 : Rb2CoCl6 (A-site effect) and Cs2TiCl6 : Cs2TiI6 :: K2CoCl6 : K2CoF6 (halide effect). Combining both gives the estimate below.

I used a halogen-substitution analogy combined with a nearest-neighbor metal proxy. Steps: (1) Observe in the dataset that replacing Cl by the larger, less electronegative I in the same A2MCl6 family (example Cs2TiCl6 -> Cs2TiI6) increases the formation energy per atom by ≈+0.6848 eV/atom (i.e., makes it less negative). (2) By symmetry of this halogen effect I infer that replacing Cl by the more electronegative, smaller F should produce a roughly opposite change (making the formation energy more negative by a similar magnitude). (3) I need an estimate for Rb2CoCl6 (not present), so I use Rb2MnCl6 = -1.839553694770114 eV/atom as a nearest-neighbor 3d metal proxy for Rb2CoCl6 (Mn and Co are adjacent 3d transition metals and the A2MCl6 formation energies vary moderately across nearby M). (4) Apply the estimated Cl->F shift (≈ -0.6848 eV/atom) to the proxy Rb2MnCl6 value to obtain Rb2CoF6 ≈ -1.83955 - 0.6848 = -2.52435 eV/atom. This yields a predicted formation energy of about -2.52 eV/atom. I note this approach assumes (a) the halogen substitution effect has similar magnitude across different metals and A-site cations and (b) Mn is a reasonable proxy for Co; these approximations introduce uncertainty of a few tenths of an eV.
code:
proxy_cl = -1.839553694770114  # Rb2MnCl6 (used as proxy for Rb2CoCl6)
cl_to_i_shift_cs_ti = (-1.376752052515965) - (-2.06158007574074)  # Cs2TiI6 - Cs2TiCl6
cl_to_f_assumed = -cl_to_i_shift_cs_ti  # assume roughly symmetric magnitude
prediction = proxy_cl + cl_to_f_assumed
prediction
math:
prediction = Rb2CoCl6_proxy + (Cl -> F shift)
Cl -> F shift ≈ - (Cs2TiI6 - Cs2TiCl6) = -0.684827 eV/atom
Rb2CoF6 ≈ -1.83955369477 + (-0.684827) = -2.52438069477

analogy: I use an analogy based on A2MCl6 halide double-perovskites to estimate Rb2CoF6. Steps: 1) Start from a chemically similar 3d A2MCl6 example: Cs2MnCl6 (formation energy = -1.69665 eV/atom) as a baseline for an A2MCl6 with a 3d transition metal. 2) Account for the A-site size effect by comparing Cs2MnCl6 (-1.69665) to K2MnCl6 (-1.64146): going from Cs -> smaller alkali (K) makes the formation energy less negative by +0.0552 eV/atom. Rb is intermediate between Cs and K, so I apply a partial correction of +0.03 eV/atom to go from Cs->Rb. 3) Account for the transition-metal substitution Mn -> Co: both are neighboring 3d elements; I assume a modest additional stabilization for Co of about -0.05 eV/atom relative to Mn (small change). 4) Account for halide substitution Cl -> F: fluorides are typically more strongly bound (more negative formation energy) than chlorides. Based on typical halide trends in the dataset (Cl->I changes of ~+0.2–0.6 eV/atom depending on cation) and using a conservative Cl->F stabilization of -0.25 eV/atom, I apply that correction. Combined: baseline (Cs2MnCl6) -1.69665 + A-site Cs->Rb (+0.03) + M-site Mn->Co (-0.05) + halide Cl->F (-0.25) = -1.96665 eV/atom. Thus by analogy: Cs2MnCl6 : K2MnCl6 :: Rb2CoF6 : (predicted) and the predicted formation energy per atom for Rb2CoF6 is approximately -1.97 eV/atom. The reasoning acknowledges uncertainty in each empirical delta and chooses conservative corrections, so the value should be considered an estimate with an uncertainty of a few 0.1 eV/atom.
code:
baseline = -1.696653019942529  # Cs2MnCl6
delta_Cs_to_Rb = 0.03
delta_Mn_to_Co = -0.05
delta_Cl_to_F = -0.25
prediction = baseline + delta_Cs_to_Rb + delta_Mn_to_Co + delta_Cl_to_F
prediction
